CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection rejected (non-exhaustion);Violation of Art. 5-1;Not necessary to examine Art. 5-2;No violation of Art. 3;No violation of Art. 8;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a NORP national who was born in DATE and resides in GPE .

In DATE he was called up for military service but his duty to report for service was suspended until DATE because of his studies . Prior to this date he declared in writing to the army that he objected to performing any kind of military or substitute civilian service .

On DATE he presented himself at ORG ( pääesikunta , huvudstaben ) and submitted a petition against military service . After having reiterated his petition DATE he was arrested on suspicion of having avoided service . He was eventually brought to the barracks of ORG ( PERSON barracks ” ) at PERSON , where he had been due to report on DATE . On his renewed objection to carrying out military duties his arrest was prolonged on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( kihlakunnanoikeus , häradsrätten ) of ORG ordered the applicant ’s detention on remand in FAC of GPE . On DATE ORG convicted and sentenced him to imprisonment ( suspended ) for having avoided military service from DATE to DATE and for having committed an offence in service on DATE ( Chapter DATE , Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL , of the DATE LAW ( rikoslaki , strafflag CARDINAL as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ) .

The above offences applied to conscripts like the applicant who refused to perform either military or substitute civilian service . Punishment imposed for such refusal did not relieve the conscript from his duty to serve , which ORG applied until DATE birthday ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Military Service Act ) .

CARDINAL . NORP Immediately upon his release on DATE , military staff brought the applicant back to the PERSON barracks . Subsequently , as he persisted in objecting to military service , he was re - arrested and placed in detention on remand .
On DATE ORG convicted him of a further offence in service and sentenced him to imprisonment . The sentence was to be served at DATE .

CARDINAL . On his release DATE , military personnel brought the applicant back to the PERSON barracks . As he continued to object to carrying out military service he was re - arrested and detained on remand .
On CARDINAL DATE ORG convicted the applicant of a further offence in service and sentenced him to imprisonment . The sentence was to be served at DATE .
CARDINAL . After his release on the same date he was again brought back to the PERSON barracks by the military police , where he was re - arrested as he persisted in objecting to military service .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant started to serve his sentences at FAC . When released on parole on DATE he was again taken to the FAC barracks by the military police , but since he continued to refuse military service he was re - arrested and placed in detention on remand .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted the applicant of CARDINAL offences in service and sentenced him to further imprisonment . The sentence was to be served at DATE . ORG in addition revoked the order to release the applicant on parole .
CARDINAL . After the court hearing on DATE , the applicant was , as had occurred on previous occasions , taken back to FAC before being released .

In the ORG check - out room , a military police squad consisting of conscripts and headed by NORP , a corporal , waited for the applicant . In the prison courtyard he was handcuffed and informed of his arrest . He was subsequently taken to the military police vehicle outside the prison gate . Members of his support group , who had been waiting for him outside the gate , were photographing and videotaping the incident .
He was then taken back to the PERSON barracks at LOC , situated QUANTITY from GPE , a journey which normally takes TIME by car .
Following his arrival at the PERSON barracks , the applicant was taken to the military hospital at the compound . He was released from his handcuffs in the hospital ’s entry hall .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , the measures taken by the military police had all been against his will . In the ORG ’s submission , he had consented to being transported to the military hospital .

CARDINAL . The applicant did not undergo any medical examination at the military hospital but was subjected to further questioning by army personnel on DATE , during which he renewed his objection to military service . As a result he was re - arrested at TIME on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again ordered his detention on remand in LOC . On DATE he started serving the aggregated prison sentence imposed by ORG on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

On DATE the applicant was convicted of an offence committed in service on DATE and sentenced to further imprisonment . In its judgment ORG stated that he had been deprived of his liberty as from DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was released from prison on parole . As he continued to object to military service he was twice detained on remand , in DATE and DATE , and was convicted of further offences in service and sentenced to further imprisonment .
On CARDINAL DATE the applicant was discharged from his military service for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a petition with ORG ( eduskunnan oikeusasiamies , riksdagens justitieombudsman ; “ the Ombudsman ” ) , complaining in particular about the deprivation of his liberty from DATE and the related handcuffing . He emphasised that at no moment had he attempted to escape from the military police or otherwise shown any intention of doing so . He had also been handcuffed on DATE and DATE while being transported to FAC after ORG hearings .

In his petition the applicant also submitted that , on his arrival at the Brigade on DATE , NORP had asked him whether he would agree to go to the military hospital . The applicant had then restated his objection to performing any kind of service but he had not consented to going to the hospital , as was shown by the fact that he had been handcuffed until his arrival there . At any rate , he had not acted in a way which could lead anyone to believe that he had wished to receive hospital care .

CARDINAL . Heard as a suspect at the ORG ’s request , PERSON stated that he had been instructed by ORG of the PERSON barracks to bring the applicant back to the compound . After the applicant had been released in the prison courtyard , NORP had ordered the military police to apprehend him . According to the training provided to members of military police squads , a person who was to be arrested was to be informed thereof and was also to be handcuffed . On the applicant ’s return to the PERSON barracks , NORP had been instructed by the Duty Officer to ask the applicant whether he would agree to take up his military service . As he objected he had , with his own consent , been brought to the military hospital . As far as NORP could remember , the applicant had been released from his manacles in the hospital yard .

CARDINAL . NORP The army authority in ORG told the ORG that the purpose of the applicant ’s apprehension had been to ensure that he would remain in the hands of the military authorities , given that he had been ordered to take up his service at that compound . The military police had not been given any instructions concerning his transportation in handcuffs . Nor did the situation as a whole seem to have required such a measure , considering that his arrest had not been ordered and , as on previous occasions , he was only to be returned to the FAC barracks . In view of his repeated convictions for military offences , NORP had nevertheless considered that the applicant ’s handcuffing was necessary in order to ensure his return to the PERSON barracks .

CARDINAL . ORG made the following observations to the ORG . The applicant ’s arrest had taken place immediately on his release by the prison authorities . There was no evidence at that time that he continued to object to performing military service or to returning to his military compound with the military police . The measures ordered by ORG appeared to have been based on the applicant ’s earlier repeated objections to performing any kind of service and the likelihood that this would continue . Moreover , his support group had been disturbing NORP during the incident .

ORG nevertheless conceded that , on the basis of the evidence available , there had been no acceptable grounds for arresting the applicant , which measure had stemmed from the fact that NORP had made an incorrect assessment of the situation in combination with the surrounding circumstances . Nor had there been any justification for handcuffing the applicant . According to the relevant permanent instructions , manacles could be used temporarily in order to calm down a person behaving violently who was to remain in the hands of the authorities or if there was a specific reason for suspecting that he would escape . Although the applicant had , on several occasions , committed punishable acts and his support group had attended his release from FAC , it had not been likely that he would escape on that occasion .

CARDINAL . In his decision of CARDINAL DATE the ORG noted that the military authorities had had no reason to fear that the applicant would attempt to escape . On previous occasions the latter had in fact presented himself voluntarily to them . The ORG considered that the applicant ’s arrest on DATE had lacked a legal basis since , prior to the measure , he had not been asked whether he would persist in his refusal to perform military or substitute service . The ORG furthermore stated :
“ There were no objectively justifiable grounds for putting PERSON in handcuffs . Apparently NORP proceeded in this situation as he had been trained to do .

When evaluating the actions of NORP , one must take into consideration his inexperience and the rather general nature of the directions which he had received from his brigade . NORP himself believed that he acted in accordance with orders . A more experienced military person should have been assigned to fetch PERSON from FAC . It is not even claimed that NORP ’s behaviour was inappropriate in any other respect . In my opinion , and taking into consideration the circumstances , this action does not call for measures to be taken against NORP by the ORG . ”

In addition , he urged ORG and the PERSON Commander to see to it that in both the training and activities of the military police a clear distinction was made between situations arising in times of peace and of war .
The ORG did not order that criminal charges be brought .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätten ) of PERSON convicted the applicant of refusal to carry out military service under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Military Service Act ( asevelvollisuuslaki , värnpliktslag CARDINAL/CARDINAL , as amended with effect from DATE ) . This provision authorised the punishment of a conscript who categorically objected to performing military service , who did not opt for substitute civilian service and whose behaviour would not change as a result of punishment imposed under LAW of LAW . ORG sentenced him to CARDINAL days’ imprisonment . Since he had already served DATE of his previous sentences , this was considered sufficient .

CARDINAL . According to LAW DATE ( sotilaskurinpitolaki , militär disciplinlag CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , a person caught committing a military offence or suspected on likely grounds of having committed such an offence may be arrested provided this is necessary in order to maintain or restore discipline , order or safety ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . According to the DATE LAW ( rikoslaki , strafflag CARDINAL ) , a soldier carrying out police duties is entitled , if he encounters resistance , to use the necessary force justified by the circumstances ( Chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL , as added by Act no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . According to the DATE ORG intended for the members of the military police force , a person who is to be transported shall be handcuffed . Its preface states that it is principally intended for use in wartime or when there is a threat of war . It underlines that in peacetime the military police shall not use more violence than the situation calls for when , for instance , transporting an arrested person .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § § CARDINAL of the LAW ( Suomen hallitusmuoto , ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) provides :

“ Anyone whose rights have been infringed or who has suffered damage as a result of an illegal act or negligence by a civil servant , is entitled to claim that the civil servant be punished and ordered to pay compensation for damages or to demand that he or she be prosecuted in accordance with the rules provided for by law .
Whether and to what extent the ORG is liable to pay damages caused by civil servants , is to be governed by specific provisions . ”

CARDINAL . A civil servant who , by intent or neglect or carelessness , acts or omits to act in breach of his or her professional duties as provided for in statute or regulation is liable to punishment , if the act or omission is not insignificant , having regard to the damage caused and other circumstances ( LAW , ORG CARDINAL of LAW ) .
LAW provides that the failure to observe military duties may also be considered under the particular offences laid down in LAW .

According to LAW , a member of the armed forces who , by intent or neglect or negligence , fails to comply with the relevant military rules and regulations is liable to disciplinary sanctions or to imprisonment of DATE . Specific provisions on disciplinary measures are contained in LAW DATE ( sotilaskurinpitolaki , militär disciplinlag CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . If ORG receives a petition against a public official or authority concerning a matter falling within his area of competence , he or she is to carry out an investigation . If the ORG suspects that the person or authority concerned has committed an unlawful act or a fault calling for his intervention , he or she must inform and hear that person or authority . If the matter can not rest by the ORG expressing criticism , he or she must prosecute , or have prosecuted , the person who is suspected of being guilty of the unlawful conduct or order that disciplinary proceedings be instituted against the latter ( Rule CARDINAL of ORG to ORG , GPE oikeusasiamiehen johtosääntö , PERSON för riksdagens justitieombudsman CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . A person who has been deprived of his or her liberty for TIME or more may claim compensation from the ORG under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW by the State for the Deprivation of the Liberty of Detained or Convicted Innocent Persons ( laki CARDINAL syyttömästi vangitulle tai tuomitulle valtion varoista vapauden menetyksen johdosta maksettavasta korvauksesta , lag CARDINAL om ersättning av statens medel som till följd av frihetsberövande skall betalas till oskyldigt häktad eller dömd , hereinafter referred to as “ the Compensation for Deprivation of Liberty Act ” ) .

CARDINAL . Under LAW DATE ( vahingonkorvauslaki , skadeståndslag CARDINAL ) proceedings may also be brought against the ORG in respect of damage resulting from fault or neglect by its employees in the performance of their duties ( Chapters CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

In a decision of DATE , ORG ordered the ORG to pay compensation under LAW DATE to a person who , after causing disturbance at the emergency unit of a hospital , had been arrested and left by the police at a forest road QUANTITY from the town centre . Although it had been lawful to arrest him , ORG considered that the measure had been carried out in a manner which constituted a breach of the police ORG professional duties and which had caused suffering deserving of compensation to the person concerned . In addition it ordered the police officers to pay fines .
